item.title: OnPaper Podcast-Maria Rodale of Rodale Inc.
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Maria Rodale of Rodale Inc.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode, Rodale shares her extensive research and family business's documented history as an organic pioneer, to illustrate why chemical-free farm systems are important to healthy environments and strong economies.
?We?re not deciding for ourselves about the chemicals in our environment and in our bodies, unless we?re choosing organic,? Rodale states.
Understanding the relationship between the health of earth?s soil and people?s health is a part of the company?s rich history. Almost thirty years ago, Rodale?s father started a side-by-side comparison of organic versus chemical agriculture, entitled the Farming Systems Trial, the results of which garnered attention from scientists around the globe.
?Organic farming is more productive, more profitable, more fuel efficient. And the surprise finding {from the Farming Systems Trial} was that organically farmed soil actually sequesters huge amounts of carbon, which means that it actually is one of the primary solutions to global warming.?
item.itunes:keywords: sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, green business, energy, Maria Rodale, Rodale, Rodale Institute, organic farming
item.description:

Understanding the relationship between the health of earth?s soil and people?s health is a part of the company?s rich history. Almost thirty years ago, Rodale?s father started a side-by-side comparison of organic versus chemical agriculture, entitled the Farming Systems Trial, the results of which garnered attention from scientists around the globe.
?Organic farming is more productive, more profitable, more fuel efficient. And the surprise finding {from the Farming Systems Trial} was that organically farmed soil actually sequesters huge amounts of carbon, which means that it actually is one of the primary solutions to global warming.?

item.title: OnPaper Podcast-Skip Elliott of CSX
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Skip Elliott of CSX.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode, Elliott shares how railroads are an energy efficient way to move goods on land, and offers listeners insight into how CSX has helped lead the industry in becoming the most environmentally-friendly transport option. In fact, according to CSX, trains can move a ton of freight more than 436 miles on a single gallon of fuel.
"CSX is an important part of the sustainable supply chain," Elliott states. "And as our customers and consumers in general are increasingly focused on the footprint of a product, the environmental advantage of shipping goods by rail is becoming even more apparent."
As a Charter Member of the EPA Smart Way Program and the first railroad to join the EPA's Climate Leaders Program, CSX is committed to developing long-term, comprehensive climate change strategies. In addition to inventorying its own greenhouse gas footprint, in 2008 CSX launched an online carbon calculator that calculates the carbon dioxide emissions savings of transporting freight by rail, thereby providing shippers and other interested parties the ability to select an environmentally sound shipping option among the many options available.
Additionally, since 2000, CSX has invested more than $1 billion to upgrade its locomotive fleet with technology that reduces both fuel consumption and air pollutant emissions. Through these efforts, the company has improved its fuel efficiency by approximately 90 percent since 1980.
Further demonstrating CSX's commitment to the environment, Elliott shares with On Paper listeners, "As part of the Climate Leaders Program, CSX announced a plan to reduce the company's CO2 emission intensity by 8 percent by 2011. That's the equivalent of taking 441,000 cars off the road each year or burning almost six million fewer barrels of oil."
item.itunes:keywords: EPA, Smart Way, Climate Leaders, climate change, transportation, transport, sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, green business, Skip Elliott, CSX, railroads
item.description:
In this episode, Elliott shares how railroads are an energy efficient way to move goods on land, and offers listeners insight into how CSX has helped lead the industry in becoming the most environmentally-friendly transport option. In fact, according to CSX, trains can move a ton of freight more than 436 miles on a single gallon of fuel.
"CSX is an important part of the sustainable supply chain," Elliott states. "And as our customers and consumers in general are increasingly focused on the footprint of a product, the environmental advantage of shipping goods by rail is becoming even more apparent."
As a Charter Member of the EPA Smart Way Program and the first railroad to join the EPA's Climate Leaders Program, CSX is committed to developing long-term, comprehensive climate change strategies. In addition to inventorying its own greenhouse gas footprint, in 2008 CSX launched an online carbon calculator that calculates the carbon dioxide emissions savings of transporting freight by rail, thereby providing shippers and other interested parties the ability to select an environmentally sound shipping option among the many options available.
Additionally, since 2000, CSX has invested more than $1 billion to upgrade its locomotive fleet with technology that reduces both fuel consumption and air pollutant emissions. Through these efforts, the company has improved its fuel efficiency by approximately 90 percent since 1980.
Further demonstrating CSX's commitment to the environment, Elliott shares with On Paper listeners, "As part of the Climate Leaders Program, CSX announced a plan to reduce the company's CO2 emission intensity by 8 percent by 2011. item.title: OnPaper Podcast-Jill Dumain of Patagonia
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Jill Dumain of Patagonia.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Dumain explains how Patagonia, a leading producer of quality outdoor clothing, uses business to inspire and implement solutions to the environmental crisis. Through participation in numerous organizations and industry efforts, Patagonia has collaborated with suppliers and competitors alike, to minimize the potential impact their worldwide supply chain and production practices could have on the earth.
"We realize our company is much smaller than the people we have the potential to influence," explains Dumain. "We have to influence companies larger than us if we are going to reach that ultimate goal."
As a founding member of the Organic Exchange, a business-to-business effort to stabilize the organic fiber market, Patagonia helped balance fiber supply with demand and as a result the Exchange is now examining the broader topic of sustainable textiles. And through participation in the Outdoor Industry Association's Eco-Working Group, Patagonia is helping to develop an eco-index for consumer products which will help outdoor companies, both large and small, measure where they are on the environmental impact scale, in turn offering guidance to make informed decisions regarding the production of their goods.
It is experiences like these, Dumain shares with On Paper, that have shown other companies the benefit of sharing environmental research, even with competitors.
"We can work behind the scenes and share this information, that really is pre-competitive, and still compete on the merits of our design, durability, color, style," Dumain explains. "It?s very powerful because it takes a lot of time to do environmental research and work. If you can share that with colleagues in other companies, everybody moves ahead so much faster."
item.itunes:keywords: Patagonia, Organic Exchange, fiber supply, eco-index, organic fiber, sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, green business, Jill Dumain, Outdoor Industry

And through participation in the Outdoor Industry Association's Eco-Working Group, Patagonia is helping to develop an eco-index for consumer products which will help outdoor companies, both large and small, measure where they are on the environmental impact scale, in turn offering guidance to make informed decisions regarding the production of their goods.

item.title: On Paper Podcast- Robert Bernard of Microsoft
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Robert Bernard, Chief Environmental Strategist at Microsoft.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Bernard discusses how technology and software can be leveraged to drive real change in the global environment. Bernard outlines three areas of focus where Microsoft can make a positive impact regarding sustainability by: enabling significant energy efficiency in and through the use of IT, accelerating scientific breakthroughs in research on environmental based issues, and becoming responsible environmental leaders on a daily basis through the way they do business.
"We went from a world where we had a lot of interested people, to a world where now all of our field staff who talk to our customers and many of our engineers who are writing software, are thinking about and acting on the new vision and paradigm that we?re moving toward," Bernard explains. "We're taking this incredible creative power that the company has, and we're getting people to start thinking and acting in an expanded dimension, with a deliberate focus on energy and environmental sustainability."
For more information on the smart grid document referenced in this episode, please visit www.smart2020.org/.
"We went from a world where we had a lot of interested people, to a world where now all of our field staff who talk to our customers and many of our engineers who are writing software, are thinking about and acting on the new vision and paradigm that we?re moving toward," Bernard explains. "We?re taking this incredible creative power that the company has, and we?re getting people to start thinking and acting in an expanded dimension, with a deliberate focus on energy and environmental sustainability."
For more information on the smart grid document referenced in this episode, please visit www.smart2020.org/.
item.itunes:keywords: Microsoft, smart grid, technology, software, global environment, sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, green business, energy, Robert Bernard, environmental sustainability

item.title: On Paper Podcast-11/30/09- Christopher Lloyd of Verizon
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Verizon from Fortune Brainstorm: Green
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Chris Lloyd, Verizon's Executive Director of Public Policy and Strategic Alliances discusses Verizon?s involvement with the group Global e-Sustainability Initiative (GeSI). Lloyd outlines four areas where the group believes that information communication technology (ICT) can play a role in promoting more energy efficient behavior: using ICT and broadband to facilitate the development of smart grids, smart buildings, smart transportation and travel substitution.
"The smart grid is going to deliver for electricity what the internet delivers for information," says Lloyd. "We think by overlaying broadband and integrating it into the electric grid, it is going to make it a lot smarter." Lloyd further explains how communication technology and broadband technology combined in smart grids will provide consumers with demand side management information in order to make more energy efficient decisions in their household energy consumption.
item.itunes:keywords: Verizon, information communication technology, ICT, smart grid, broadband, energy efficient, sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, Fortune Brainstorm Green, green business, energy
item.description:

item.title: On Paper Podcast-11/30/09- Arlin Wasserman of Sodexo
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Sodexo from Fortune Brainstorm: Green
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Arlin Wasserman, Sodexo's Vice President of Corporate Citizenship, discusses Sodexo's unique role as the world?s largest provider of institutional food and facilities management services, and their ability to help businesses and institutions attain sustainability objectives. Wasserman looks to three main areas to achieve these objectives: impact on communities; health, wellness and nutrition; and environmental impact.
"When you look at the numbers, there is no bigger sector that has an impact on the planet and how people treat the planet, than the food and agriculture sector. And no bigger sector that has an impact on how people are going to use energy and interact with the climate then putting that together with facilities management sector," explains Wasserman. By moving the industry to measurable performance, Wasserman explains how Sodexo's efforts have helped reduce environmental impact while promoting ecological restoration.
item.itunes:keywords: Sodexo, facilities management, sustainability, environment, NewPage Corporation, environmentalism, green, ecology, Fortune Brainstorm Green, green business, carbon management, agriculture, ecological restoration
item.description:
In this episode of On Paper, Arlin Wasserman, Sodexo's Vice President of Corporate Citizenship, discusses Sodexo's unique role as the world?s largest provider of institutional food and facilities management services, and their ability to help businesses and institutions attain sustainability objectives. Wasserman looks to three main areas to achieve these objectives: impact on communities; health, wellness and nutrition; and environmental impact.
"When you look at the numbers, there is no bigger sector that has an impact on the planet and how people treat the planet, than the food and agriculture sector. And no bigger sector that has an impact on how people are going to use energy and interact with the climate then putting that together with facilities management sector," explains Wasserman. By moving the industry to measurable performance, Wasserman explains how Sodexo's efforts have helped reduce environmental impact while promoting ecological restoration.

item.title: On Paper Podcast-10/28/09- NewPage Corporation and WRI
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with NewPage Corporation and World Resources Institute, from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Rick Willett, former President and CEO of NewPage Corporation and Craig Hanson, Director of People & Ecosystems at the World Resources Institute, discuss the benefits of corporate - nonprofit partnerships, while outlining their current collaboration on Project POTICO (Palm Oil, Timber, Carbon Offsets). Project POTICO is a bold three-year, multi-million dollar initiative led by WRI and fully funded by NewPage Corporation to preserve endangered virgin rainforests in Indonesia, a region known for its high deforestation rate.
Project POTICO addresses the underlying economics of deforestation due to unsustainable palm oil cultivation. "We are really supportive of long-term forest management," Willett explains. "We have very good forestry practices in North America where the forests are well managed and are growing faster than they are being harvested. However, there are still issues internationally, and playing a role in having the world subscribe to a global standard for well managed forests is very important to our company, customers and employees."
Visit projectPOTICO.org for more information.
item.itunes:keywords: environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, WRI, World Resources Institute, Forestry, green business
item.description:
In this episode of On Paper, Rick Willett, former President and CEO of NewPage Corporation and Craig Hanson, Director of People & Ecosystems at the World Resources Institute, discuss the benefits of corporate - nonprofit partnerships, while outlining their current collaboration on Project POTICO (Palm Oil, Timber, Carbon Offsets). Project POTICO is a bold three-year, multi-million dollar initiative led by WRI and fully funded by NewPage Corporation to preserve endangered virgin rainforests in Indonesia, a region known for its high deforestation rate.
Project POTICO addresses the underlying economics of deforestation due to unsustainable palm oil cultivation. "We are really supportive of long-term forest management," Willett explains. "We have very good forestry practices in North America where the forests are well managed and are growing faster than they are being harvested. However, there are still issues internationally, and playing a role in having the world subscribe to a global standard for well managed forests is very important to our company, customers and employees."
Visit projectPOTICO.org for more information.

item.title: On Paper Podcast-9/30/09- Lorie Wigle of Intel
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Intel from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
In this episode of On Paper, Lorie Wigle, Eco-Technology General Manager for Intel, discusses the company's strategies for making their products better for the environment, particularly through improved energy efficiency.
Interviewed at Fortune Brainstorm: Green with host Maureen Kedes, Wigle also discusses the potential of applying ICT to reduce CO2 in other industries, through developing applications such as smart grids and smarter modeling tools. "Computers and communications equipment account for about 2% of global CO2 (emissions). But, we have an opportunity to have a huge impact on the other 98%," says Wigle.
item.itunes:keywords: smart grid, eco-technology, ICT, environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, Intel, energy efficiency, green business, Lorie Wigel
item.description:

"Computers and communications equipment account for about 2% of global CO2 (emissions). But, we have an opportunity to have a huge impact on the other 98%," says Wigle.

item.title: On Paper Podcast-9/18/09- Bob Langert of McDonalds
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with McDonalds from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
Interviewed at Fortune Brainstorm: Green with host Maureen Kedes, Bob Langert, VP of Corporate Responsibility for McDonald's, discusses the tremendous potential for efficiencies in the restaurant company's supply chain.
Langert informs listeners of McDonald?s work to reduce packaging waste, and their cooperation with Greenpeace to transform their agricultural practices in the Amazon. "When we can make transformative change in supply chain, and it has a trickle effect to other retailers and suppliers, to me that is a lasting legacy," says Langert.
item.itunes:keywords: Greenpeace, reduce waste, agricultural practices, corporate responsibility, environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, McDonalds, supply chain, green business, Bob Langert
item.description:

item.title: On Paper Podcast-8/17/09- Kathy Abusow of Sustainable Forestry Initiative
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with Kathy Abusow of SFI from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
As a provider of Chain of Custody certification, the Sustainable Forestry Initiative (SFI) tracks fiber on its journey from forests to the printers. In this episode of On Paper, Kathy Abusow, President & CEO of SFI discusses their role in promoting responsible forestry.
"What we want the world to know is that you can look for the SFI label on a product and know that that product comes from a well-managed forest," says Abusow.
item.itunes:keywords: chain of custody, CoC, responsible forestry, certification, fiber, environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, SFI, Sustainable Forestry Initiative, Kathy Abusow, forestry, green business,
item.description:
As a provider of Chain of Custody certification, the Sustainable Forestry Initiative (SFI) tracks fiber on its journey from forests to the printers. In this episode of On Paper, Kathy Abusow, President & CEO of SFI discusses their role in promoting responsible forestry.
"What we want the world to know is that you can look for the SFI label on a product and know that that product comes from a well-managed forest," says Abusow.

item.title: On Paper Podcast-8/9/09- Drew Schramm of Herman Miller
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with furniture manufacturer Herman Miller, from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
Setting social responsibility goals before it was in fashion, Herman Miller has had a long legacy and continued vision to create with a sustainable supply chain. Interviewed at Fortune Brainstorm: Green with On Paper host Maureen Kedes, Drew Schramm, Sr. VP Global Supply & Quality for Herman Miller discusses strategy, design and the importance of transparency in managing our environmental footprints.
"We?ve worked so hard at Herman Miller to make sure that we are doing absolutely the right thing for the environment and doing it in a very upfront way," says Schramm.
item.itunes:keywords: footprint, strategy, design, furniture, transparency, environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, Herman Miller, supply chain, green business, Drew Schramm

item.title: On Paper Podcast-7/8/09- Richard Lechner of IBM
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with IBM from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
"What we hope is, at IBM, is that through our Smarter Planet Initiative, by making the macro system smarter through the use of technology, that we can fundamentally change the way the world works." ? Richard Lechner
In this episode of On Paper, Richard Lechner, Vice President, IT Optimization, shares his thoughts on investing in sustainability for infrastructure, operations and industry solutions, as well as IBM's Project Big Green and Smarter Planet initiative.
item.itunes:keywords: Smarter Planet Initiative, Project Big Green, technology, green tech, IT optimization, environment, environmentalism, green, ecology, sustainability, NewPage Corporation, Fortune Brainstorm Green, IBM, energy, green business, Richard Lechner

item.title: On Paper Podcast-6/18/09- Guy Gleysteen of TIME Inc.
item.itunes:author: NewPage Corporation
item.itunes:subtitle: An interview with TIME Inc. from Fortune Brainstorm Green.
item.itunes:summary:
"Our sustainability initiatives are all about making sure that the fiber that our suppliers procure is done in a manner that protects the forests, protects resources and helps us maintain a trust with our customers." - Guy Gleysteen
Interviewed at Fortune Brainstorm: GREEN, Guy Gleysteen, Senior Vice President of Production for Time Inc., discusses the power of paper and the importance of forestry certification with On Paper host Maureen Kedes.
